facts.text: Dr. S. Dutt is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hidayatullah, J. Dr. S. Dutt who appeals to this Court by special leave against the judgment and order of Mr. Justice Misra of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow

facts.text: Dr. S. Dutt examined as expert witness by defence in Sessions trial State v. Matadin and Ors. S.T. No. 60 of 1957 in Court of Additional Sessions Judge, Hardoi.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that offence falls under ss.193/196 IPC not 465/471, requiring court complaint under s.195 CrPC.

issues.text: Whether the offence falls under ss.465/471 IPC or under ss.193/196 IPC

anchor.surface_text: His contention, however, is that the offence, if any, was not under s. 465 nor under s. 471, but one under s. 193 or 196, Indian Penal Code for which the procedure of s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was imperative.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the offence in the present case did number fall within ss. 465/471, I.P.C. and the prosecution launched against Dr. Dutt cannot be allowed to go on.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of ss.463,464 shows no 'making' of false document by accused; ss.24,25 exclude dishonest/fraudulent use as production was under court order without intent for wrongful gain/loss or inducement to disadvantageous action.

holdings.text: The prosecution launched against Dr. Dutt cannot be allowed to go on.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the offence in the present case did number fall within ss. 465/471, I.P.C. and the prosecution launched against Dr. Dutt cannot be allowed to go on.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts primarily disclose offence under ss.193/196 IPC requiring s.195 CrPC complaint; prosecution under ss.465/471 is evasion via misdescription, prohibited by Basir-ul-Huq precedent.

holdings.text: Dr. Dutt did not make a false document within the definition in s.464 IPC; no forgery under s.463/465.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out at once that it was not suggested before us that Dr. Dutt made a false document within the definition of the expression in s. 464 of the Indian Penal Code. In fact, there was no complaint that he committed the forgery himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution case is not that accused personally forged per any clause of s.464; diploma was forged but not by him.

holdings.text: Production of diploma under court order does not constitute dishonest or fraudulent use as genuine under s.471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: He was said to have, used a false document as genuine dishonestly and fraudulently. ... It is a matter of some doubt whether he can be said to have used the diploma because he did not voluntarily bring the diploma to court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No wrongful gain/loss per s.24 (dishonestly); no intent to defraud per s.25 requiring inducement to act to disadvantage (citing Buckley J definition, Welham); production compelled by order, not voluntary; cites precedents on non-use.

holdings.text: Dr. Dutt's conduct falls within s.196 IPC as corruptly using evidence known to be false.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it falls within s. 196 which casts its net wider in the interest of the purity of administration of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.196 requires only 'corruptly' (wider than dishonest/fraudulent, morally debased; cites Emperor v. Rana Nana, Bibkhranjan Gupta); applies to using diploma knowing false to mislead judge.

holdings.text: Chapter XI ss.193/196 IPC (false evidence/public justice) applies, not Chapter XVIII ss.465/471 (documents).

anchor.surface_text: Sections 465 and 471 occur in Chapter XVIII -of the Indian Penal Code which deals with offences relating to documents... Sections 193 and 196 occur in Chapter XI which deals with false evidence and offences against public justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gist of Ch.XVIII is making/use of false documents; Ch.XI is procuring false evidence/documents for judicial proceedings to cause erroneous opinion; facts fit latter, determining s.195 applicability.

holdings.text: Dr. Dutt's conduct covered by s.192 IPC (fabricating false evidence).

anchor.surface_text: Section 192 then defines compendiously the offence of fabricating false evidence. The portion which Mr. Chari claims applies here may be set out Whoever causes... The definition... quite clearly covers this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accused made/produced document containing false statement intending it appear in evidence to cause judge erroneous opinion on his expertise, material to trial.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.195 CrPC cannot be evaded by selecting lesser offences like ss.465/471 to bypass court complaint.

anchor.surface_text: s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure must number be evaded if the bar created by it stands in the way ... The test whether there -is evasion of the section or number is whether the facts disclose primarily

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Basir-ul-Huq test: primary offence on facts requires complaint; choosing 2yr offence over 7yr s.196 to avoid Sessions Judge refusal uncommendable.

anchor.surface_text: Basir-ul-Huq and Others v. The State of West Bengal and Nur-ul-Huda v. The State of West Bengal 1 , where it is observed that s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure must number be evaded if the bar created by it stands in the way  1  1963 S.C.R. 836 at 842.

precedents.case_name: Basir-ul-Huq v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of section 195 CrPC cannot be evaded by resorting to devices or camouflages; test is whether facts disclose primarily an offence requiring complaint of the court
precedents.cited_holding: Though section 195 does number bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by the same facts... cannot be evaded by the devices of charging a person with an offence to which that section does number apply...

precedents.citation: Emperor v. Rana Nana 1 ... I.L.R 46 Bom. 317

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor v. Rana Nana 1  Chief Justice Macleod companysidered the word to be of wider import than the words fraudulently or dishonestly and did number companyfine it to the taking, of bribes or cases of bribery. I.L.R 46 Bom. 317.

precedents.cited_proposition: "corruptly" is of wider import than "fraudulently" or "dishonestly" and not confined to taking of bribes

precedents.citation: Bibkhranjan Gupta v. The King, 2 ... 2 I.L.R. 1949 2 Cal. 440

anchor.surface_text: In Bibkhranjan Gupta v. The King,  2  Mr. Justice Sen dealt at length with this word. He was companytrasting s. 196 with s. 471 and observed that the word companyruptly was number synonymous with dishonestly or fraudulently but was much wider. According to him it even included companyduct which was neither fraudulent number dishonest if it was otherwise blameworthy or improper.  2  I.L.R. 1949 2 Cal. 440.

precedents.cited_proposition: "corruptly" not synonymous with "dishonestly" or "fraudulently" but wider, includes blameworthy or improper conduct even if not fraudulent or dishonest

precedents.citation: Assistant Sessions Judge North Arcot v. Ranaminal 1 ... LI-R. 36 Mad. 387

precedents.citation: In re London and Globe Finance Corp. Ltd  1903  1 ch. 728

anchor.surface_text: In re London and Globe Finance Corp. Ltd  1903  1 ch. 728 . There has been much dispute in recent years as to what Lord Buckley meant by the words deprived by deceit.

precedents.case_name: In re London and Globe Finance Corp. Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between 'to deceive' (induce belief in false thing) and 'to defraud' (deprive by deceit, induce action to injury)
precedents.cited_holding: To deceive is... to induce a man to believe that a thing is true which is false... To defraud is to deprive by deceit it is by deceit to induce a man to act to his injury.

precedents.citation: Welbam v. Director of Public Prosecutions 1  1961 A.C. 103

anchor.surface_text: The House of Lords in Welbam v. Director of Public Prosecutions 1  ruled that it is number necessary that there must be an intention to cause an economic loss. ... 1  1961 A.C. 103.

precedents.case_name: Welham v. Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents.cited_proposition: Intent to defraud does not require intention to cause economic loss
